text: foreign
[Music]
stigma because we wanted to give people
a safe place to practice talking about
their mental health mental health is a
practice it's just like your physical
health if you invest in your physical
health and you do certain activities you
will have stronger physical health when
it comes to your mental health same is
true and we see stigma as one of the
many tools someone can have in their
toolkit to better manage their emotion
understand what they're feeling and give
labels to the things that are making
them struggle
[Music]
the stigma app was designed to make it
easier to talk about your mental health
so whether you're having a hard day and
feeling overwhelmed and you want to use
our asynchronous messaging tool to ask
for support from the community or you're
someone who just wants to practice
offering hope and doing something kind
for others because you have a little
hope to spare we are a platform that is
crowdsourcing hope
I am one of the 46 of Americans who
lives with a diagnosed mental illness
and I have people in my life who I love
who also live with mental illness so
that was really the origin of my
inspiration but we know that people who
are struggling often find it hard to ask
for help or to talk about what they're
going through so our app was designed to
help people who feel emotionally
overwhelmed or who are struggling find
relief and relief can look like talking
to someone who's been through what
you've been through through our
asynchronous messaging tool it can look
like working through some of the
negative stories that you tell yourself
to put a more hopeful frame on them and
it can also look like finding resources
that you might not have known existed
that you find because you're willing to
be open and vulnerable and share
[Music]
when we think about how we're monitoring
user engagement and behavior in the
platform one of the most important areas
is moderation of content when someone
asks for Hope or when someone offers
hope even when there's an AI generated
offer of hope we're moderating that
content and what we wanted to do was
build the back end build something from
the ground up that would let us moderate
the content and approve or deny posts
that met our community guidelines or
didn't by having everything in one place
and being able to see the ways in which
people Engage The Cadence of Engagement
we're able to look at how we're growing
over time and we've hit some Milestones
like taking the average amount of time
it takes for someone to get an offer of
Hope down from days to minutes
[Music]
there's a saying in startups that
Capital Is Like Oxygen if you don't have
it you die and programs like the AWS
impact accelerator Latino cohort take
people like me who are underrepresented
founders who are first-time Founders
non-technical Founders and give us the
non-dilutive capital that give us the
runway to be able to test our ideas and
validate if it's something that the
world needs and customers want to pay
for
[Music]
as a non-technical Founder I was a
little overwhelmed about how I was going
to bring this idea I had to crowdsource
hope to life but with API economy
Solutions we were able to build an MVP
that we stood up pretty quickly pretty
inexpensively and validate that people
actually wanted this thing that we were
building
over time what we realized though is
that we needed to make the experience
better specifically in the area of how
quickly can we get people an offer of
hope we had an idea for how we wanted to
utilize AI to be able to make that
happen and we were able in our time in
the AWS accelerator to work with some of
the brightest Minds at AWS on AI to
figure out exactly how we could bring it
to life quickly
one of my favorite things to talk about
is how far we've come since we launched
a web application that we stood up for
fourteen thousand dollars and how we
became this mobile app that within three
months of launching was named 2022's
best app for good where we are today and
where we were before has a lot to do
with our participation in the AWS impact
accelerator Latino cohort the reason why
is we came in knowing what we wanted to
do from a tech perspective we got a
great Tech Mentor who was able to
connect us to some of the brightest
Minds in AI at AWS and we not only
figured out what was possible in those
eight weeks but what we could continue
to work to build with their support
after we left the program
since ending the AWS impact accelerator
eight weeks ago the momentum has not
stopped for stigma eight weeks ago we
were participating in the closing
ceremony of the NASDAQ and today I'm
headed to Wrigleyville to throw the
opening pitch at a Cubs game
if I let some of the reasons why I
wouldn't be a successful founder shape
my experience I wouldn't be where I am
today I was born in Costa Rica to a
father with schizophrenia I came to the
U.S and was on food stamps and preschool
lunch programs I'm a solo non-technical
founder and a single mom there are so
many cards stacked against me but I
believed in what I was building and I
didn't stop I kept working I kept having
conversations I kept finding programs
with non-diluted capital and I was able
to turn a dream that I had into a
reality that's helping thousands of
people every day no matter who you are
or what kind of adversity you've faced
if you are someone who has a dream for
something that you want to build don't
wait to get started just start moving
you do not have to have all of the
answers what you really need is an
organization that believes in you
supporters and most importantly a belief
in yourself I believed in myself and now
I'm headed to Wrigleyville to throw the
opening pitch at a cup stand
[Music]
foreign
